mil3.6.1:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, is the body dear to recluses?”

mil3.6.1:1.3.eng: “No, your majesty, the body is not dear to recluses.”

mil3.6.1:1.4.pli: “Atha kissa nu kho, bhante, kelāyatha mamāyathā”ti?
mil3.6.1:1.4.eng: “Then, venerable sir, why do you cherish and treasure it?”

mil3.6.1:1.5.pli: “Kiṃ pana te, mahārāja, kadāci karahaci saṅgāmagatassa kaṇḍappahāro hotī”ti?
mil3.6.1:1.5.eng: “But, your majesty, when you have gone into battle have you been struck by arrows from time to time?”

mil3.6.1:1.7.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, so vaṇo ālepena ca ālimpīyati telena ca makkhīyati sukhumena ca coḷapaṭṭena paliveṭhīyatī”ti?
mil3.6.1:1.7.eng: “And would the wound, your majesty, be anointed with a salve, smeared with oil, and wrapped in a soft bandage?”

mil3.6.1:1.8.pli: “Āma, bhante, ālepena ca ālimpīyati telena ca makkhīyati sukhumena ca coḷapaṭṭena paliveṭhīyatī”ti.
mil3.6.1:1.8.eng: “Yes, venerable sir, the wound would be.”

mil3.6.1:1.9.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, piyo te vaṇo, tena ālepena ca ālimpīyati telena ca makkhīyati sukhumena ca coḷapaṭṭena paliveṭhīyatī”ti?
mil3.6.1:1.9.eng: “And was the wound dear to you, your majesty, that it was anointed with a salve, smeared with oil, and wrapped in a soft bandage?”

mil3.6.1:1.10.pli: “Na me, bhante, piyo vaṇo, api ca maṃsassa ruhanatthāya ālepena ca ālimpīyati telena ca makkhīyati sukhumena ca coḷapaṭṭena paliveṭhīyatī”ti.
mil3.6.1:1.10.eng: “No, venerable sir, the wound was not dear to me, it was for the healing of the flesh that it was anointed with a salve, smeared with oil, and wrapped in a soft bandage.”

mil3.6.1:1.11.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, appiyo pabbajitānaṃ kāyo, atha ca pabbajitā anajjhositā kāyaṃ pariharanti brahmacariyānuggahāya.
mil3.6.1:1.11.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, the body is not dear to recluses, but recluses look after the body without attachment for the maintenance of the holy life.

mil3.6.1:1.12.pli: Api ca kho, mahārāja, vaṇūpamo kāyo vutto bhagavatā, tena pabbajitā vaṇamiva kāyaṃ pariharanti anajjhositā.
mil3.6.1:1.12.eng: And moreover, your majesty, the body is said by the Blessed One to be like a wound, and therefore recluses look after the body as they would a wound without attachment.

mil3.6.1:1.13.eng: And this too was said, your majesty, by the Blessed One:

mil3.6.1:2.2.eng: the great wound with nine openings

mil3.6.1:4.1.eng: Love of the Body Question first

mil3.6.10:0.3.eng: 10. Question on Remembrance of What was Done Long Ago

mil3.6.10:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, how does one remember what was done long ago in the past?”

mil3.6.10:1.4.pli: “Nanu, bhante nāgasena, cittena sarati no satiyā”ti?
mil3.6.10:1.4.eng: “Is it not, Venerable Nāgasena, that one remembers with one’s mind and not with mindfulness?”

mil3.6.10:1.5.pli: “Abhijānāsi nu tvaṃ, mahārāja, kiñcideva karaṇīyaṃ katvā pamuṭṭhan”ti?
mil3.6.10:1.5.eng: “Do you not know personally, your majesty, about some task you have done and have forgotten?”

mil3.6.10:1.7.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho tvaṃ, mahārāja, tasmiṃ samaye acittako ahosī”ti?
mil3.6.10:1.7.eng: “Then were you, your majesty, on that occasion without a mind?”

mil3.6.10:1.8.pli: “Na hi, bhante, sati tasmiṃ samaye nāhosī”ti.
mil3.6.10:1.8.eng: “Certainly not, venerable sir, on that occasion there was no mindfulness.”

mil3.6.10:1.9.eng: “So, why do you say, your majesty, that

mil3.6.10:1.10.eng: one remembers with one’s mind and not with mindfulness?”

mil3.6.10:3.1.eng: Question on Remembrance of What was Done Long Ago tenth

mil3.6.11:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, sabbā sati abhijānantī uppajjati, udāhu kaṭumikāva satī”ti?
mil3.6.11:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, does all mindfulness arise through knowing directly or does it come with outside help?”

mil3.6.11:1.3.eng: “By knowing directly, your majesty, and with outside help.”

mil3.6.11:1.4.pli: “Evañhi kho, bhante nāgasena, sabbā sati abhijānantī, natthi kaṭumikā satī”ti?
mil3.6.11:1.4.eng: “If thus, Venerable Nāgasena, all mindfulness is from directly knowing, there is none with outside help.”

mil3.6.11:1.5.pli: “Yadi natthi, mahārāja, kaṭumikā sati, natthi kiñci sippikānaṃ kammāyatanehi vā sippāyatanehi vā vijjāṭṭhānehi vā karaṇīyaṃ, niratthakā ācariyā, yasmā ca kho, mahārāja, atthi kaṭumikā sati, tasmā atthi kammāyatanehi vā sippāyatanehi vā vijjāṭṭhānehi vā karaṇīyaṃ, attho ca ācariyehī”ti.
mil3.6.11:1.5.eng: “If there were no mindfulness with outside help, your majesty, then artisans would have no need for practice, or craftsmanship, or schooling, and teachers would be useless, but since there is mindfulness with outside help, the opposite is true.”

mil3.6.2:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, is the Buddha all-knowing and all-seeing?”

mil3.6.2:1.3.eng: “Yes, your majesty, the Buddha is all-knowing and all-seeing.”

mil3.6.2:1.4.pli: “Atha kissa nu kho, bhante nāgasena, sāvakānaṃ anupubbena sikkhāpadaṃ paññapesī”ti?
mil3.6.2:1.4.eng: “Then why, Venerable Nāgasena, did he proclaim the training steps for his disciples gradually?”

mil3.6.2:1.5.pli: “Atthi pana te, mahārāja, koci vejjo, yo imissaṃ pathaviyaṃ sabbabhesajjāni jānātī”ti?
mil3.6.2:1.5.eng: “But, your majesty, is there some doctor who knows all the medicines on this earth?”

mil3.6.2:1.7.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, so vejjo gilānakaṃ sampatte kāle bhesajjaṃ pāyeti, udāhu asampatte kāle”ti?
mil3.6.2:1.7.eng: “And would that doctor, your majesty, administer medicine to a sick person at the time of being ill or when not ill?”

mil3.6.2:1.8.pli: “Sampatte kāle, bhante, gilānakaṃ bhesajjaṃ pāyeti, no asampatte kāle”ti?
mil3.6.2:1.8.eng: “He would administer medicine to a sick person, venerable sir, at the time of being ill and not when not ill.”

mil3.6.2:1.9.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhagavā sabbaññū sabbadassāvī na asampatte kāle sāvakānaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ paññāpeti, sampatte kāle sāvakānaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ paññāpeti yāvajīvaṃ anatikkamanīyan”ti.
mil3.6.2:1.9.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, the Blessed One who is all-knowing and all-seeing did not proclaim a training rule to his disciples at the wrong time, but when the time was right he proclaimed a training rule to his disciples, which is not to be transgressed all life long.”

mil3.6.3:0.3.eng: 3. Characteristics of a Great Person Question

mil3.6.3:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, buddho dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato asītiyā ca anubyañjanehi parirañjito suvaṇṇavaṇṇo kañcanasannibhattaco byāmappabho”ti?
mil3.6.3:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, was the Buddha endowed with the thirty-two characteristics of a great person and distinguished with the eighty secondary features, with radiant complexion, skin like gold, and a halo that extends for one fathom?”

mil3.6.3:1.3.pli: “Āma, mahārāja, bhagavā dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato asītiyā ca anubyañjanehi parirañjito suvaṇṇavaṇṇo kañcanasannibhattaco byāmappabho”ti.

mil3.6.3:2.1.pli: “Kiṃ panassa, bhante, mātāpitaropi dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgatā asītiyā ca anubyañjanehi parirañjitā suvaṇṇavaṇṇā kañcanasannibhattacā byāmappabhā”ti?
mil3.6.3:2.1.eng: “But, venerable sir, were his mother and father endowed with the thirty-two characteristics of a great person … and a halo that extends for one fathom?”

mil3.6.3:2.2.pli: “No cassa, mahārāja, mātāpitaro dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgatā asītiyā ca anubyañjanehi parirañjitā suvaṇṇavaṇṇā kañcanasannibhattacā byāmappabhā”ti.

mil3.6.3:3.1.pli: “Evaṃ sante kho, bhante nāgasena, na uppajjati buddho dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato asītiyā ca anubyañjanehi parirañjito suvaṇṇavaṇṇo kañcanasannibhattaco byāmappabhoti, api ca mātusadiso vā putto hoti mātupakkho vā, pitusadiso vā putto hoti pitupakkho vā”ti.
mil3.6.3:3.1.eng: “That being so, venerable sir, is it not then that the Buddha arose endowed with the thirty-two characteristics of a great person … and a halo that extends for one fathom? But surely a child is like their mother or those on their mother’s side or like their father or those on their father’s side.”

mil3.6.3:3.3.eng: “But is there, your majesty, any lotus with a hundred leaves?”

mil3.6.3:3.5.eng: “And where then is the origin for that?”

mil3.6.3:3.6.eng: “It is born from mud and it thrives in water.”

mil3.6.3:3.7.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, padumaṃ kaddamena sadisaṃ vaṇṇena vā gandhena vā rasena vā”ti?
mil3.6.3:3.7.eng: “Then, your majesty, is the lotus like the mud in colour, smell, or taste?”

mil3.6.3:3.9.pli: “Atha udakena vā gandhena vā rasena vā”ti?
mil3.6.3:3.9.eng: “Or is it like the water in smell or taste?”

mil3.6.3:3.11.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhagavā dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato asītiyā ca anubyañjanehi parirañjito suvaṇṇavaṇṇo kañcanasannibhattaco byāmappabho, no cassa mātāpitaro dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgatā asītiyā ca anubyañjanehi parirañjitā suvaṇṇavaṇṇā kañcanasannibhattacā byāmappabhā”ti.
mil3.6.3:3.11.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, the Buddha was endowed with the thirty-two characteristics of a great person and distinguished with the eighty secondary features, with radiant complexion, skin like gold, and a halo that extends for one fathom, and his parents were not.”

mil3.6.3:5.1.eng: Characteristics of a Great Person Question third

mil3.6.4:0.3.eng: 4. Celibacy of the Blessed One Question

mil3.6.4:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, was the Buddha a Brahma-farer (celibate)?”

mil3.6.4:1.3.eng: “Yes, your majesty, the Buddha was celibate.”

mil3.6.4:1.4.pli: “Tena hi, bhante nāgasena, buddho brahmuno sisso”ti?
mil3.6.4:1.4.eng: “Well then, Venerable Nāgasena, was the Buddha a student of Brahmā?”

mil3.6.4:1.5.eng: “But, your majesty, do you have a chief elephant?”

mil3.6.4:1.7.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, so hatthī kadāci karahaci koñcanādaṃ nadatī”ti?
mil3.6.4:1.7.eng: “And does this elephant, your majesty, roar the ‘Heron’s roar’ from time to time?”

mil3.6.4:1.9.pli: “Tena hi, mahārāja, so hatthī koñcasakuṇassa sisso”ti?
mil3.6.4:1.9.eng: “Well then, your majesty, is this elephant a student of the heron?”

mil3.6.4:1.11.eng: “Was Brahmā, your majesty, one with intelligence or without?”

mil3.6.4:1.13.eng: “Well then, your majesty, Brahmā was a student of the Blessed One.”

mil3.6.4:3.1.eng: Celibacy of the Blessed One Question fourth

mil3.6.5:0.3.eng: 5. Higher Ordination of the Blessed One Question

mil3.6.5:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, is the higher ordination good?”

mil3.6.5:1.3.eng: “Yes, your majesty, the higher ordination is good.”

mil3.6.5:1.4.pli: “Atthi pana, bhante, buddhassa upasampadā, udāhu natthī”ti?
mil3.6.5:1.4.eng: “But, Venerable Nāgasena, did the Buddha receive the higher ordination or not?”

mil3.6.5:1.5.pli: “Upasampanno kho, mahārāja, bhagavā bodhirukkhamūle saha sabbaññutañāṇena, natthi bhagavato upasampadā aññehi dinnā, yathā sāvakānaṃ, mahārāja, bhagavā sikkhāpadaṃ paññapeti yāvajīvaṃ anatikkamanīyan”ti.
mil3.6.5:1.5.eng: “The Blessed One, your majesty, reached the highest attainment at the foot of the Bodhi tree, together with omniscience. There was no giving of ordination to the Blessed One by others, in the way that the Blessed One proclaimed a training rule to his disciples, which is not to be transgressed all life long.”

mil3.6.5:3.1.eng: Higher Ordination of the Blessed One Question fifth

mil3.6.6:0.3.eng: 6. Question on Tears Being a Medicine or Not

mil3.6.6:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, yo ca mātari matāya rodati, yo ca dhammapemena rodati, ubhinnaṃ tesaṃ rodantānaṃ kassa assu bhesajjaṃ, kassa na bhesajjan”ti?
mil3.6.6:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, those who weep on the death of a mother, and those who weep with affection for the Dhamma, for whom of these two weeping are the tears a medicine, and for whom are the tears not a medicine?”

mil3.6.6:1.3.pli: “Ekassa kho, mahārāja, assu rāgadosamohehi samalaṃ uṇhaṃ, ekassa pītisomanassena vimalaṃ sītalaṃ.
mil3.6.6:1.3.eng: “The tears of one, your majesty, are hot and stained with lust, anger, and delusion, and the tears of the other are cool and unstained with rapture and joy.

mil3.6.6:1.4.pli: Yaṃ kho, mahārāja, sītalaṃ, taṃ bhesajjaṃ, yaṃ uṇhaṃ, taṃ na bhesajjan”ti.
mil3.6.6:1.4.eng: That which is cool, your majesty, is a medicine; that which is hot is not a medicine.”

mil3.6.6:3.1.eng: Question on Tears Being a Medicine or Not sixth

mil3.6.7:0.3.eng: 7. Question on the Difference Between Being With Attachment and Without Attachment

mil3.6.7:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, kiṃ nānākaraṇaṃ sarāgassa ca vītarāgassa cā”ti?
mil3.6.7:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, what is the difference between being with attachment and being without attachment?”

mil3.6.7:1.3.eng: “One is sticky, your majesty, and the other is not sticky.”

mil3.6.7:1.4.eng: “What is the meaning, venerable sir, of ‘sticky’ and ‘not sticky’?”

mil3.6.7:1.5.eng: “One is desirable, your majesty, and the other is not desirable.”

mil3.6.7:1.6.pli: “Passāmahaṃ, bhante, evarūpaṃ yo ca sarāgo, yo ca vītarāgo, sabbopeso sobhanaṃyeva icchati khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā, na koci pāpakaṃ icchatī”ti.
mil3.6.7:1.6.eng: “As I see it, venerable sir, both the one with attachment and the one without attachment wish for beautiful hard and soft food, and neither wishes for something bad.”

mil3.6.7:1.7.pli: “Avītarāgo kho, mahārāja, rasapaṭisaṃvedī ca rasarāgapaṭisaṃvedī ca bhojanaṃ bhuñjati, vītarāgo pana rasapaṭisaṃvedī bhojanaṃ bhuñjati, no ca kho rasarāgapaṭisaṃvedī”ti.
mil3.6.7:1.7.eng: “One who is not without attachment, your majesty, eats their food and experiences both the taste and the attachment to the taste. But the one who is without attachment eats their food and experiences just the taste and not the attachment to the taste.”

mil3.6.7:3.1.eng: Question on the Difference Between Being With Attachment and Without Attachment seventh

mil3.6.8:0.3.eng: 8. Question on the Establishment of Wisdom

mil3.6.8:1.4.eng: “Then, Venerable Nāgasena, is there no wisdom?”

mil3.6.8:1.5.eng: “Where does the wind reside, your majesty?”

mil3.6.8:1.7.eng: “Then, your majesty, is there no wind?”

mil3.6.8:3.1.eng: Question on the Establishment of Wisdom eighth

mil3.6.9:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, yaṃ panetaṃ brūsi ‘saṃsāro’ti, katamo so saṃsāro”ti?
mil3.6.9:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, as to which you said ‘cyclic existence’. What is this cyclic existence?”

mil3.6.9:1.3.pli: “Idha, mahārāja, jāto idheva marati, idha mato aññatra uppajjati, tahiṃ jāto tahiṃyeva marati, tahiṃ mato aññatra uppajjati, evaṃ kho, mahārāja, saṃsāro hotī”ti.
mil3.6.9:1.3.eng: “Your majesty, that which is born here dies here, and having died here, it arises elsewhere. Then, having been born there it dies there, and having died there, it arises elsewhere. Thus, your majesty, this is cyclic existence.”

mil3.6.9:1.5.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, kocideva puriso pakkaṃ ambaṃ khāditvā aṭṭhiṃ ropeyya, tato mahanto ambarukkho nibbattitvā phalāni dadeyya, atha so puriso tatopi pakkaṃ ambaṃ khāditvā aṭṭhiṃ ropeyya, tatopi mahanto ambarukkho nibbattitvā phalāni dadeyya, evametesaṃ rukkhānaṃ koṭi na paññāyati;
mil3.6.9:1.5.eng: “Just as, your majesty, some person may eat a ripe mango and plant the seed. Then, when it has grown up as a mature mango tree, it would give fruit. And then that man might eat a ripe mango from it and plant the seed and, when it has grown up as a mature mango tree, it too would give fruit. And thus, no end to these mango trees can be discerned.

mil3.6.9:1.6.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, idha jāto idheva marati, idha mato aññatra uppajjati, tahiṃ jāto tahiṃyeva marati, tahiṃ mato aññatra uppajjati, evaṃ kho, mahārāja, saṃsāro hotī”ti.
mil3.6.9:1.6.eng: In the same way, your majesty, that which is born here dies here, and having died here, it arises elsewhere. Then, having been born there it dies there, and having died there, it arises elsewhere. Thus, your majesty, this is cyclic existence.”

mil3.7.1:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, in how many ways does mindfulness arise?”

mil3.7.1:1.3.eng: “Your majesty, mindfulness arises in seventeen ways.”

mil3.7.1:1.5.pli: “Abhijānatopi, mahārāja, sati uppajjati, kaṭumikāyapi sati uppajjati, oḷārikaviññāṇatopi sati uppajjati, hitaviññāṇatopi sati uppajjati, ahitaviññāṇatopi sati uppajjati, sabhāganimittatopi sati uppajjati, visabhāganimittatopi sati uppajjati, kathābhiññāṇatopi sati uppajjati, lakkhaṇatopi sati uppajjati, sāraṇatopi sati uppajjati, muddātopi sati uppajjati, gaṇanātopi sati uppajjati, dhāraṇatopi sati uppajjati, bhāvanatopi sati uppajjati, potthakanibandhanatopi sati uppajjati, upanikkhepatopi sati uppajjati, anubhūtatopi sati uppajjatīti.
mil3.7.1:1.5.eng: “Mindfulness arises, your majesty, through knowing directly, with outside help, from consciousness of a substantiality, from consciousness of welfare, from consciousness of misfortune, from a common sign, from an uncommon sign, from understanding due to speech, from a distinguishing characteristic, from remembering, from reckoning, from calculation, from bearing in mind, from mental development, from recording in books, from association of ideas, and from experience.

mil3.7.1:2.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise through knowing directly?

mil3.7.1:2.2.pli: Yathā, mahārāja, āyasmā ca ānando khujjuttarā ca upāsikā, ye vā pana aññepi keci jātissarā jātiṃ saranti, evaṃ abhijānato sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:2.2.eng: Just as, your majesty, Venerable Ānanda or the female lay follower Khujjuttarā or those others who remember past births remember a past birth, thus does mindfulness arise through knowing directly.

mil3.7.1:3.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise with outside help?

mil3.7.1:3.2.pli: Yo pakatiyā muṭṭhassatiko, pare ca taṃ sarāpanatthaṃ nibandhanti, evaṃ kaṭumikāya sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:3.2.eng: If others urge one who is naturally muddled in mindfulness so that he remembers, thus does mindfulness arise with outside help.

mil3.7.1:4.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise from consciousness of a substantiality?

mil3.7.1:4.2.pli: Yadā rajje vā abhisitto hoti, sotāpattiphalaṃ vā patto hoti, evaṃ oḷārikaviññāṇato sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:4.2.eng: When there is a consecration into sovereignty or the attainment of the fruit of stream entry, thus does mindfulness arise from consciousness of a substantiality.

mil3.7.1:5.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise from consciousness of welfare?

mil3.7.1:5.2.pli: Yamhi sukhāpito, ‘amukasmiṃ evaṃ sukhāpito’ti sarati, evaṃ hitaviññāṇato sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:5.2.eng: One remembers when one was happy, ‘There was happiness because of that.’ Thus, does mindfulness arise from consciousness of welfare.

mil3.7.1:6.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise from consciousness of misfortune?

mil3.7.1:6.2.pli: Yamhi dukkhāpito, ‘amukasmiṃ evaṃ dukkhāpito’ti sarati, evaṃ ahitaviññāṇato sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:6.2.eng: One remembers when one was suffering, ‘There was suffering because of that.’ Thus, does mindfulness arise from consciousness of misfortune.

mil3.7.1:7.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise from a common sign?

mil3.7.1:7.2.pli: Sadisaṃ puggalaṃ disvā mātaraṃ vā pitaraṃ vā bhātaraṃ vā bhaginiṃ vā sarati, oṭṭhaṃ vā goṇaṃ vā gadrabhaṃ vā disvā aññaṃ tādisaṃ oṭṭhaṃ vā goṇaṃ vā gadrabhaṃ vā sarati, evaṃ sabhāganimittato sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:7.2.eng: Having seen a person similar to oneself one remembers his mother, father, brother, or sister, and having seen a camel, an ox, or a donkey, one remembers a camel, an ox, or a donkey. Thus, does mindfulness arise from a common sign.

mil3.7.1:8.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise from an uncommon sign?

mil3.7.1:8.2.pli: Asukassa nāma vaṇṇo ediso, saddo ediso, gandho ediso, raso ediso, phoṭṭhabbo edisoti sarati, evampi visabhāganimittatopi sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:8.2.eng: When one remembers that such is the colour of a certain thing, such the sound, such the smell, such the taste, such the touch, thus does mindfulness arise from an uncommon sign.

mil3.7.1:9.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise from understanding due to speech?

mil3.7.1:9.2.pli: Yo pakatiyā muṭṭhassatiko hoti, taṃ pare sarāpenti, tena so sarati, evaṃ kathābhiññāṇato sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:9.2.eng: If others remind one who is naturally muddled in mindfulness so that he remembers, thus does mindfulness arise from understanding due to speech.

mil3.7.1:10.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise from a distinguishing characteristic?

mil3.7.1:10.2.pli: Yo pakatiyā balībaddānaṃ aṅgena jānāti, lakkhaṇena jānāti, evaṃ lakkhaṇato sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:10.2.eng: One who knows an ox based on a conventional factor, remembers it by its distinguishing characteristic. Thus, does mindfulness arise from a distinguishing characteristic.

mil3.7.1:11.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise from remembering?

mil3.7.1:11.2.pli: Yo pakatiyā muṭṭhassatiko hoti, yo taṃ ‘sarāhi bho, sarāhi bho’ti punappunaṃ sarāpeti, evaṃ sāraṇato sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:11.2.eng: If one causes someone who is usually muddled in mindfulness to remember by repeatedly saying, ‘Remember, sir! Remember, sir!’ thus does mindfulness arise from remembering.

mil3.7.1:12.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise from reckoning?

mil3.7.1:12.2.pli: Lipiyā sikkhitattā jānāti ‘imassa akkharassa anantaraṃ imaṃ akkharaṃ kātabban’ti evaṃ muddāto sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:12.2.eng: From being trained in writing, one knows, ‘This letter is to be made immediately after that letter.’ Thus, does mindfulness arise from reckoning.

mil3.7.1:13.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise from calculation?

mil3.7.1:13.2.pli: Gaṇanāya sikkhitattā gaṇakā bahumpi gaṇenti, evaṃ gaṇanāto sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:13.2.eng: From being trained in calculation, accountants calculate even very large sums. Thus, does mindfulness arise from calculation.

mil3.7.1:14.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise from bearing in mind?

mil3.7.1:14.2.pli: Dhāraṇāya sikkhitattā dhāraṇakā bahumpi dhārenti, evaṃ dhāraṇato sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:14.2.eng: From being trained in bearing in mind, those who bear in mind can remember even a large amount. Thus, does mindfulness arise from from bearing in mind.

mil3.7.1:15.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise from mental development?

mil3.7.1:15.2.pli: Idha bhikkhu anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—
mil3.7.1:15.2.eng: Here, a bhikkhu recalls his various past lives, that is,

mil3.7.1:15.4.pli: iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, evaṃ bhāvanāto sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:15.4.eng: such that he remembers them with all their aspects and features. Thus, does mindfulness arise from mental development.

mil3.7.1:16.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise from recording in books?

mil3.7.1:16.2.pli: Rājāno anusāsaniyaṃ assarantā etaṃ potthakaṃ āharathāti, tena potthakena anussaranti, evaṃ potthakanibandhanato sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:16.2.eng: A king’s minister when not remembering an administrative rule might have a book brought to him, and then would remember by means of that book. Thus, does mindfulness arise from from recording in books.

mil3.7.1:17.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise from association of ideas?

mil3.7.1:17.2.pli: Upanikkhittaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ disvā sarati, evaṃ upanikkhepato sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:17.2.eng: When one remembers after seeing goods laid aside, thus does mindfulness arise from association of ideas.

mil3.7.1:18.1.eng: How does mindfulness arise from experience?

mil3.7.1:18.2.pli: Diṭṭhattā rūpaṃ sarati, sutattā saddaṃ sarati, ghāyitattā gandhaṃ sarati, sāyitattā rasaṃ sarati, phuṭṭhattā phoṭṭhabbaṃ sarati, viññātattā dhammaṃ sarati, evaṃ anubhūtato sati uppajjati.
mil3.7.1:18.2.eng: From what was seen one remembers material form, from what was heard one remembers sound, from what was smelled one remembers odour, from what was tasted one remembers flavour, from what was touched one remembers tangibles, from what was cognised one remembers thought. Thus, does mindfulness arise from experience.

mil3.7.1:18.3.pli: Imehi kho, mahārāja, sattarasahākārehi sati uppajjatī”ti.
mil3.7.1:18.3.eng: In these seventeen ways, your majesty, mindfulness arises.”

mil3.7.10:1.3.pli: ‘aṭṭhikāni dīghāni yojanasatikānipī’ti, rukkhopi tāva natthi yojanasatiko, kuto pana aṭṭhikāni dīghāni yojanasatikāni bhavissantī”ti?
mil3.7.10:1.3.eng: ‘There are long bones extending one hundred yojanas.’ Since there is no tree extending that far, how then could there be long bones extending one hundred yojanas?”

mil3.7.10:2.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, sutaṃ te ‘mahāsamudde pañcayojanasatikāpi macchā atthī’”ti?
mil3.7.10:2.1.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, have you heard that in the great ocean there are fish extending for five hundred yojanas?”

mil3.7.10:2.2.eng: “Yes, venerable sir, I have heard so.”

mil3.7.10:2.3.pli: “Nanu, mahārāja, pañcayojanasatikassa macchassa aṭṭhikāni dīghāni bhavissanti yojanasatikānipī”ti?
mil3.7.10:2.3.eng: “Is it not, your majesty, that the long bones of such a fish would extend for a hundred yojanas?”

mil3.7.11:0.3.eng: 11. Question on the Cessation of In and Out Breathing

mil3.7.11:1.3.eng: ‘It is possible to cease in and out breathing’?”

mil3.7.11:1.4.eng: “Yes, your majesty, it is possible to cease in and out breathing.”

mil3.7.11:1.5.eng: “How, Venerable Nāgasena, is it possible to cease in and out breathing?”

mil3.7.11:1.6.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, sutapubbo te koci kākacchamāno”ti.
mil3.7.11:1.6.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, have you heard before of someone snoring?”

mil3.7.11:1.7.eng: “Yes, venerable sir, I have heard of it.”

mil3.7.11:1.8.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, so saddo kāye namite virameyyā”ti.
mil3.7.11:1.8.eng: “Would that sound be stopped, your majesty, if the body were bent?”

mil3.7.11:1.10.pli: “So hi nāma, mahārāja, saddo abhāvitakāyassa abhāvitasīlassa abhāvitacittassa abhāvitapaññassa kāye namite viramissati, kiṃ pana bhāvitakāyassa bhāvitasīlassa bhāvitacittassa bhāvitapaññassa catutthajjhānaṃ samāpannassa assāsapassāsā na nirujjhissantī”ti.
mil3.7.11:1.10.eng: “Since, your majesty, that sound would be stopped if the body were bent by someone undeveloped in body, virtue, mind, and wisdom, why could not the breathing in and the breathing out be ceased for someone developed in body, virtue, mind, and wisdom, and who has attained the fourth jhāna?”

mil3.7.11:3.1.eng: Question on the Cessation of In and Out Breathing eleventh

mil3.7.12:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, ‘samuddo samuddo’ti vuccati, kena kāraṇena udakaṃ ‘samuddo’ti vuccatī”ti?
mil3.7.12:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, it is called ‘the sea, the sea’. Why is the water called the sea?”

mil3.7.12:1.4.eng: “Just as much as there is water, your majesty, so much there is salt.

mil3.7.12:1.5.eng: Just as much as there is salt, so much there is water.

mil3.7.13:0.3.eng: 13. Question on the One Taste of the Sea

mil3.7.13:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, kena kāraṇena samuddo ekaraso loṇaraso”ti?
mil3.7.13:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, why does the sea have just one taste, the taste of salt?”

mil3.7.13:1.3.pli: “Cirasaṇṭhitattā kho, mahārāja, udakassa samuddo ekaraso loṇaraso”ti.
mil3.7.13:1.3.eng: “The sea has just one taste, the taste of salt, your majesty, because it has been around a long time.”

mil3.7.13:3.1.eng: Question on the One Taste of the Sea thirteenth
